title: Abraham's Visitors and Intercession
shortSummary: Genesis 18 recounts the LORD's visitation to Abraham in the form of three men, the promise of Isaac's birth to Sarah, and Abraham's bold intercession for the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. This chapter highlights God's faithfulness to His promises and the power of prayerful advocacy for mercy.
timeline: c. 2100 BC - Patriarchal Period during Abraham's lifetime

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch who receives divine visitors, demonstrates hospitality, and intercedes for Sodom.

keyCharacters.name: Sarah
keyCharacters.description: Abraham's wife who overhears the promise of bearing a son despite her old age.

keyCharacters.name: The Three Men
keyCharacters.description: Divine visitors representing the LORD who announce the forthcoming birth of Isaac and proceed to Sodom.

definitions.definition: A region near Hebron where Abraham dwelt and received the LORD's visitation.
Those who live in obedience to God's law and moral standards.
Engaging in intimate and direct conversation, especially with God.
A title emphasizing God's sovereign authority and perfect justice over all creation.

outline.heading: Divine Visitation and Hospitality
outline.description: The LORD appears to Abraham as three men near Mamre. Abraham shows exemplary hospitality by preparing a meal and serving them, demonstrating faith and reverence toward God's messengers.

outline.heading: Promise of Isaac's Birth
outline.description: The visitors announce that Sarah will bear a son within the appointed time. Sarah laughs in disbelief due to her old age, but God affirms that nothing is too hard for Him.

outline.heading: God's Disclosure to Abraham
outline.description: God reveals His plan to investigate the grievous sin of Sodom and Gomorrah, showing His justice and willingness to judge sin while maintaining a relationship with Abraham.

outline.heading: Abraham's Intercession for Sodom
outline.description: Abraham boldly pleads with God to spare the cities if righteous people are found, illustrating the power of intercessory prayer and God's mercy balanced with justice.

application: Practice hospitality as a way to honor God and serve others, following Abraham's example.
Trust in God's promises even when circumstances seem impossible, remembering that nothing is too hard for Him.
Approach God boldly in prayer, interceding for others with faith and humility.
Recognize God's justice and mercy, living righteously and advocating for righteousness in the world.

keyVerses.text: Is any thing too hard for the LORD? At the time appointed I will return unto thee, according to the time of life, and Sarah shall have a son.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's omnipotence and faithfulness to His promises, encouraging trust in His timing.

keyVerses.text: That be far from thee to do after this manner, to slay the righteous with the wicked: and that the righteous should be as the wicked, that be far from thee: Shall not the Judge of all the earth do right?
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God's perfect justice and the moral distinction between the righteous and the wicked.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD went his way, as soon as he had left communing with Abraham: and Abraham returned unto his place.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the intimate relationship between God and Abraham and the effectiveness of prayerful dialogue.
